title: Fed Policy Pivot Seen in the Works; Policy Paths to Diverge for Major Central Banks
text:
And, if you have questions about the outlook for growth and inflation in the U.S., please note The Wall Street Journal this Friday will host an online question-and-answer session with San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly. To join the session, see below.

Now on to today's news and analysis.

Top News

Fed Meets for First Time Since Powell Signaled Policy Shift

Federal Reserve officials meet Tuesday and Wednesday for the first time since Chairman Jerome Powell said last month that the central bank needed to shift its focus toward preventing higher inflation from becoming entrenched and away from fostering a rapid rebound in hiring from the pandemic, writes The Wall Street Journal's Nick Timiraos.

The pivot raises the prospect that the Fed's post-meeting statement—a document parsed by markets as a signal of likely future policy—could be overhauled at the conclusion of their meeting Wednesday.

"There are meetings where you make small changes, and there are meetings where you make larger changes. And this feels to me like a meeting where they're making larger changes," said William English, a former senior Fed economist who is now professor at the Yale School of Management.

Fedspeak Cheat Sheet: What Officials Said Before December Meeting

Comments by Federal Reserve officials took a decidedly hawkish turn in the weeks following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting in early November that launched the drawdown of the central bank's bond buying program. Here is a roundup of their recent comments.

Wall Street Journal Live Q&A

The Economic Outlook for 2022 with SF Fed President Mary Daly

Mary Daly, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, answers your questions Friday, Dec. 17 at 1 p.m. ET about the U.S. economic outlook and steps the Fed has taken to contain the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and to address inflation. Sign up here.

Derby's Take:

By Michael S. Derby

Economists are factoring in a more hawkish interest rate path for the Federal Reserve and expect its officials to reveal that shift in forecasts planned for release on Wednesday.

Based on comments from a range of Fed officials, economists expect that after the two-day Federal Open Market Committee meeting concludes the central bank will accelerate the pace of its so-called taper, or winding down, of its bond buying asset stimulus, with an eye toward completing it by around March. Read more.

U.S. Economy

Public's Expectations for Inflation in November 2022 Rise to Record

Respondents to a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York amid a surge in inflation said they see inflation at a record 6% in a year, up from the 5.7% gain projected in the prior month's report. The New York Fed survey started in 2013.

Why U.S. Job Gains Are So Hard to Count During Covid-19

Economists have struggled to guess the behavior of consumers and companies during unprecedented government stimulus, labor-market shifts and virus fears, and the government has seen a sharp decline in the payroll data it collects from employers.

Biden Aims to Win Pivotal Democrat's Support for $2 Trillion Plan

President Biden this week will lobby Sen. Joe Manchin, the centrist West Virginia Democrat, to try to lock in a deal on a roughly $2 trillion social-policy and climate bill Democrats hope to finish by Christmas. Passage hinges largely on Mr. Manchin.

Key Developments Around the World

Central Banks Diverge as Omicron Clouds Growth, Inflation Outlook

Policy makers at three influential central banks meet this week to provide guidance on future interest rates. They are expected to move at different speeds, reflecting varying responses to the pandemic and divergent outlooks for growth and inflation.

Canada Renews Central Bank's Inflation-Targeting Mandate

The Canadian government and Bank of Canada agreed Monday to renew the central bank's mandate to target 2% annual inflation, with an emphasis on giving the central bank flexibility to address economic challenges and help obtain full employment when conditions warrant.

As Turkey's Currency Collapses, Erdogan's Hometown Support Sinks

Here in President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's hometown on Turkey's Black Sea coast, residents are questioning the leadership of their city's favorite son amid an economic crisis that is driving up the cost of food, gasoline and medicine.

Cash Glut in Eurozone Drives Dollar Demand

Cash-rich eurozone banks are rushing to change their euros into dollars, driving a key measure of demand for the greenback. The interest rates on three-month euro cross-currency basis swaps have turned more negative in recent weeks.

Financial Regulation Roundup

What's Behind China's Regulatory Storm

China's authorities attracted the world's attention during 2021 with a series of abrupt and unanticipated regulatory and policy changes. With several strokes of the pen, regulators imposed new and more restrictive regulations on a range of sectors.

JPMorgan in Talks to Pay $200 Million Fine Over Text Messages

JPMorgan Chase & Co., the nation's biggest bank, is nearing a deal to pay a $200 million fine and admit that it failed to properly monitor employees' messages, the first settlement to emerge from a regulatory sweep into how banks oversee traders' chats.

China's SenseTime Postpones IPO After U.S. Blacklisting

Chinese artificial-intelligence company SenseTime Group Inc. said it would postpone its Hong Kong initial public offering, days after it was added to an investment blacklist of companies that the U.S. government says are supporting Chinese military development.

Research

Oxford Economics Warns Bond Yields Could Jump Next Year

The Treasury bond market has taken the Federal Reserve's reducing its asset buying with relative calm so far and yields haven't shown a huge reaction. But that could change next year and present a challenging situation for the central bank. "Declining Treasury demand from investment funds raises the risk of higher rates and volatility in 2022, particularly as the Federal Reserve winds down [quantitative easing] purchases," John Canavan, bond analyst at Oxford Economics, writes in a report. "While foreign Treasury demand has been offsetting a portion of the shrinking investment fund purchases, we don't expect it will be strong enough to compensate for the decline in both investment fund and Fed purchases next year," he adds, noting that "we anticipate a gradual increase in the 10-year Treasury yield through 2022 to around 2.25% at year-end." Late Monday, the 10-year note was at 1.40%.

—Michael S. Derby

Commentary

Why Investors Should Care About the ‘Powell Pivot'

After months of reassuring everyone that inflation was "transitory" and would go away by itself, at the end of November he abandoned the idea and warned of tighter policy ahead, writes James Mackintosh in the WSJ's Streetwise column. What the future brings depends on why he did so, and there are lots of theories, some more far fetched than others.

Biden Seems Set on Making ‘Transitory' Inflation Last

Even if inflation slows to half its current rate and the Fed follows the end of its bond buying with rate increases, that would still leave nominal growth above 8% while official interest rates are at barely 1%, Gerard Baker writes, adding that it's hard to see that as anti-inflationary.

Muddled Priorities and Monetary Policy in Beijing

Looser monetary policy will be needed both to support formal bond issuance by provincial governments—one of the few remaining fiscal channels not under pressure—and to help strong property developers raise funds to buy assets from weaker ones, Nathaniel Taplin writes.

Basis Points

U.K. banks will need a larger cushion of capital to protect against losses from December next year, the Bank of England's Financial Policy Committee, noting that from Dec. 13, 2022,the countercyclical capital buffer will increase to 1 from 0% currently. The buffer is raised or lowered depending on economic conditions, with the aim of spurring credit growth in a slump and reining in risky lending in a boom. (Dow Jones Newswires)

Oxford Economics' eurozone recovery tracker fell by 2 points in the two weeks ended Nov. 21, after a 1.1 point decline previously, as "Consumption, which has been the hope of the eurozone recovery, posted a concerning 7.3 points drop over the two weeks, highlighting that resurgent Covid cases are the main threat to consumer activity over the winter period," OE economist Rory Fennessy said. (DJN)
